answers.answer: I wouldn't give my toddler kool aid even.  Too much sugar and empty calories.  I know you can puree real food for your 8 month old - maybe mush up bananas? Does he have teeth? Be careful, they can choke easily.  Just wanted to give you my humble opinion =)

I agree with Kellie.  Kool Aid is not for babies or little kids.  As I recall, my pediatrician recommended formula and/or breast milk as the only liquids for the first year.  Then, after age 1, whole milk and watered down juices.  As far as food, I used to give my kids mashed bananas, mashed peas, grated cheese, mashed potatoes (not too thick), Cream of Wheat, scrambled eggs chopped into little pieces and tiny pieces of peaches, pears etc.  I think Cheerios would be okay at eight months too.
My ped actually encouraged water and watered down prune juice before age one. I would not do Kool-Aid either, but I think water and some juices are fine. DS is six and seems healthy enough! :)
I gave my daughter things like mashed potatoes and apple sauce.

if finger foods is what you are looking for try cooked carrots(cut small of course) when they put them in there mouth the carrots moosh up so they have less of a choking hazard.as far as kool-aid and juices...i also don't think he is old enough for kool-aid however some juices have more sugar in them than kool-aid does.~nanci

What about Freanch Fries, We where out the other night and my mother inlaw thought it was cute to give him freanch fries, they were soft ofcourse. Also my husband had ordered pizza last night and let him Nal on a piece of the Crust for his teeth.Kool-Aid NOSome juices ok!
As long as you are comfortable with it and watch him closely I don't see it as a problem. After all he is your child lol.

My seven-year-old son has diabetes (I post in the juvenile diabetes forum too).  Of course, he can only have sugar-free beverages in addition to water and milk in order to keep his glucose under control.  When he was diagnosed a year ago, I was worried about him drinking stuff with aspertame and other artificial sweeteners.  But both his diabetes specialist and his pediatrician said it was fine in moderation, and actually better for most kids than drinking sugary sodas or too much juice.  So the cup a day of Crystal Light that your child is getting sounds fine based on what my doctor told me.  My neighbor down the street who is a nurse also gives her kids Crystal Light.

My sonw as eating variety of foods at 8 months as well as breastfeeding. About that point you get the okay for diluted juice (50/50) but only about 2 ounces or so a day. Avoid apple juice as it is full of sugar and has very little nutritional value when compared to other juices. Also avoid orange juice as it is way too acidic for them.Other food to avoid until they are at least 1 year old (avoid peanuts longer if history of food allergies in family):Honeyegg whitesMilkPeanuts/Peanut ButterThese have a high incedence of allergic reactions (honey can harbor botulism as it is not pasturized) and it is recommended that you avoid feeding these foods until your child is at least 1 year old.In my own personal opinion, I never gave my son Kool-Aid, soda, sugary juices or any of that stuff when he was that young. Even at the age of 31 months, he still only gets a few ounces of caffeine free soda on special occasions and has yet to even taste Kool-Aid.Andrea

My DD hasn't ever had kool-aid and she is now 6! LOL  I just thought it was gross myself as a child so I never subjected her to it.But on another note, I read somewhere (in a time long ago and long forgotten) that the dyes in some foods and drinks can be harful, (again long ago, so I can't remember why or how). But I do remember that Kool-Aid was specifically mentioned, especially red Kool-Aid.Do any of you think Crystal Light is any better? I usually make that for DD and I to drink. She gets one cup of that a day, one cup of juice and the rest of the day it's milk and water. Just looking for an opinion on teh Crystal Light though. Or is you have a better suggestion. Oh and sometimes I do watered down gatorade for the both of us too. But then I read the other day how bad that is! LOL I swear there is nothing we can drink or eat anymore that won't kill us!

I personally dont like kool-aid, I do however occasionally make some since DH likes it. My kiddos are 3 and 19 months. At 8 months both of them liked french fries, and pizza. They atemost things as long as it was something that wasnt crunchy and a choking hazard. Chads favorite juice at that age was pear juice from gerber, I did half juice half water.

What about Kool Aid without the sugar.  Just make up a pitcher with water and mixture.  Would that work???  I have heard of people giving their kids jello water just to give the water some flavor so it is not so bland to them.  This is just a thought.  Good Luck.

I would avoid the jello water especially if it isn't sugar free. Regular Jello is loaded with sugar and I would think it would horrible for their teeth. My son is a huge water drinker, he drinks tons of water throughout the day. Juice is fine in moderation, diluted is even better. Milk is good, but avoid giving it with iron rich foods as calcium interferes with the absorption of iron and can lead to anemia. A close friends little boy was just diagnosed as being anemic and he would honestly have been the last kid I would have ever expected! He is a huge meat eater and has a great appetite. I then started asking her about his milk consumption and quickly discovered why his iron is so low, his dad gives him milk with every meal!Andrea

Wow thanks for pointing that out.  My DD usually drinks only one cup of milk a day (she gets calcium form other sources though-I try to make sure) But that cup is at dinner time. I never thought of it interfering with her iron absorption althuogh I knew myself not to take my prenatal with milk because of that fact.
Are you a doctor or nurse?  You seem very informed..

Used to be a nurse but I "retired" when I got married : ) Now I am a stay at home mom with 2 boys (6 weeks and 31 months) and I am also pursuing another degree in Early Childhood Education for giggles. This has been a great degree to pursue as it covers all areas of early childhood including health and wellness, diet, safety, development and many other areas : )Andrea

question: How old should a baby be before you start giveing them Coolaid? I was also wondering, what are some real foods (not baby foods but real foods) I can start feeding my son? He is 8months just about 9months old.
title: How  old Should a baby be..
